Just been reading through the comments, here's what I gathered.

The term Astronaut refers to someone who has gone to space.
Space means anywhere above the Earth's atmosphere where there isn't any drag and the only force acting upon the rocket is gravity.

If we were to go by these definitions, then Jeff and Co can be called astronauts.
However, here's what else I've gathered.

Astronauts are trained and tested for a long time before they are ready to go to space
Someone who is called an astronaut normally goes up there for a purpose, this can be anywhere from simply being there to take control if the ship malfunctions at all to going to space to do tasks or to stay at the ISS.

Basically, astronauts do not go to space to experience it, they are going there to do a job, space is their job, and they have been trained specifically to do that job.

By this, Jeff and co are not astronauts, they are passengers.

"Astronaut" is a profession, not an altitude. Using that term for sightseeing tourists cheapens the word and does a great disservice to actual astronauts.

Look, I'm genuinely happy space tourism is finally opening up (it should have happened decades ago), but I disagree completely with the misuse of "astronaut" by both Blue and Virgin, and the media. These people are PASSENGERS. If they wish, they can call themselves Spacefarers, Space Flyers, Space tourists, spaceflight participants, Atmo Surfers, Dildo Riders, they can call themselves anything they want, except for "Astronaut", which has a very specific meaning.

Being an astronaut involves training, discipline, commitment, mission responsibilities, etc. It's the opposite of a sightseeing joyride (and there's nothing wrong with sightseeing joyrides!). The word also has 60 years of respect and admiration associated with it which has been EARNED, not PURCHASED like a cruise ship package. It is precisely because of what actual astronauts have achieved that Blue Virgin wish to freeload off them and ride their coattails to relevance. This astronaut aura is the real product they're selling to their paying customers, which is why both companies make such a big deal about that word (Branson grotesquely calling himself "Astronaut Double Oh One") and hand out astronaut wings like participation trophies.
